text:
Hi,

How reliable is Viator to book a tour from Florence?
Thanks

comments.comment_text: Had very good luck with them.
We booked a trip to Parma the night before and it was fine.

Julie Ouellette my experience was not positive. I booked tour with Viator to Florence. I arrived at train station in Milan expecting to meet with tour guide ( as has been my experience with all other tours). There was no one and a passenger waiting to board train contacted Viator on my behalf. Viator informed me this was a “solo” trip although advertised as “guided”. Basically Viator only booked train ticket and hop-on-hop-off bus on my behalf. I arrived in Florence at 9:00am and train ticket was booked to return at 7:00pm. Therefore, I wasted an entire day in Florence waiting around to board return train to Milan.

I have used them and be very cautious. They were not what they promote. I don’t recommend.

We had no issues

text:
POSITANO VS MATERA

I have time for one but not both on my trip… which one should I choose?

I’ve dreamed of Italy forever and both look too amazing but I’d appreciate any tips on which to do this trip.

comments.comment_text: been to both definitely Matera,
Love both but Matera is way more magical. Let me know if you decide to go and need any tips x
Matera. Positano and the Amalfi Coast was beautiful but Matera just blew me away.
Both very different but would definitely choose Matera ❤️
POSITANO!!!!
I have been to both.. you would not be disappointed with either.
Positano
Loved both but MATERA would be my pick. It’s incredible!!! Read about it before you go!! The history is so fascinating!! You truly feel like you stepped back into history.
Both are fantastic. Matera is a must to see.

I've been to both, and they're both absolutely stunning in their own ways.
If you like to see Positano, youll have access to the Amalfi Coast. I'd stay in Sorrento & day trip to Positano, Ravello, Amalfi Beach & more.
If you go to Matera (Basilicata region, bordering Puglia) you'll have access to the stunning Puglia region, such as Alberobello, Ostuni, Polignano A Mare, Lecce, Molfetta, Giovinazzo, Monopoli, Bari & much more. I found this side of Italy magical, clean, not as touristy, authentic & stunning. The water views were beautiful. I'd go back there in a heartbeat!
But I did loooove Amalfi Coast too.
Look it up, see which side you'd be interested in.

Positano is super touristy. When I went, we stayed in Ravello - up the mountain, which was wonderful. They have amazing gardens, food and
Pottery. And a bus to the coast was $.50.
Matera
Matera is magic
ano
Let Marcelo drive and you can do both LOL
Positano 100%!
would it be easy to get to Matera without a car?

Materaaaaaaa the energy was electric 😍 positano is equally gorgeous but Matera has cats, you can get lost in all the paths and staircases all day. There is a hiking trail, they have free internet in the plaza, buskers, everyone is so friendly. Literally had so many locals give me different tours of their home town 😍🙌🏻 I am a bit bias because their local stories made me fall in love with the place.
Kathleen Barnes join
TR Malo
Positano in summer, Matera in winter

Thank you everyone for your replies!! As much as I would love to do both, I’ve chosen this time to go to Matera!

Guess this just means I’ll need to do another Italy trip one day and do the Amalfi coast then. Oh well! 😉

Amalfi Coast is dreamy and a must, but Matera and then on to the Puglia region make for a less crowded and touristy experience. Pick one then do the other on your next trip. This was our view from our room in Matera.
I’ve been to Positano and can’t imagine anything more magical
I’ve been to both, and very different vibe. Can’t go wrong with either.
2 absolutely different experiences. Been 2 both several times. Both incredible.
It will be 1000 degrees in Matera in August……
Definitely Matera.
Absolutely gorgeous!!!
Both places are absolutely stunning... so whichever you choose... I think you will have an amazing time!!! Those two places were amazing for me!!!!
Following
My mother was from Matera… so it has my vote. 🌹🇮🇹❤️
POSITANO - the vertical town that is best scene from the water <3

Was in Matera a few weeks ago, so unique and beautiful!
Of course this view from our Airbnb definitely helped! Positano was crazy crowded, although the nearby town of Praiano was 😍
Matera! Matera is fascinating and otherworldly. Positano was disappointing, crowded, and boring, at least from the land.
Lisa Adams Robertson
Matera, it is so unique. One of the highlights of my trip! An off the beaten track places to visit.

I don't know about Matera. We loved Positano but we were there in Dec. It was quiet except locals celebrating the feast of the immaculate conception. I think it may be a little to over run in the summer. I hope you make it to Pompeii though. It's more than I ever expected! We've been twice...once on '03 and again in '19. They have excavated so much more and added a great Pink Floyd exhibit!

Matera is magical. But you only need 2 full days or so to explore both Sasso Barisano and Sasso Caveoso.
As for Positano, you can hop on ferry or bus(unless you are driving) ti visit other towns

Depends which time of year and who you’re with. Do you have kids? We’ve just returned from a Puglia trip and we tacked on two nights in Matera at the end. It is definitely magical, especially at twilight when the lights start coming on. My kids were troopers but it was sooo hot and there was no pool or sea to swim in to cool down. And we couldn’t hike across to the caves on the hillside opposite as it was too hot or too dark. Positano is beautiful too, though I prefer amalfi and atrani. It is busy but you have the sea! If summer, I’d choose coast, if spring/autumn, then matera.
Positano forever ♥
Matera👌It is a fantastic and unique place. Two days in January'22 👌🇮🇹🇵🇱
Matera, far better than Positano in my POV.
Matera!!!!!

Just got back from our trip. Amalfi coast and Positano were beautiful. However, avoid Positano in the summer! It was crowded!!!
We did a tour with Collette we stayed at hotel Raito which I in Vietri del Mare or Vietri Del Sur? Close enough to Positano /Amalfi but far from the mayhem!
Matera!
Matera
Matera!!! All the way
I would go to Matera. It is beautiful, historic and so unexpected. Great food too.

Been to both. Positano is beautiful, but Matera is absolutely breathtaking.
Matera all the way.
Matera

It depends on what you are looking for. I was in Positano last month and was disappointed at how touristy it was. The village is lovely, the scenery is amazing, but the stores were commercialized,
I thought it was difficult to find authentic restaurants, and there were LOTS and LOTS of people. I never saw traffic when cars weren’t gridlocked. And boat traffic was very congested. Obviously a lot of people like this experience, but if you are looking for a more relaxed vacation, I would suggest somewhere else.

Two very different places Matera an amazing story...Positan
o an amazing place to see. Matera is a one day visit. Positano needs a few days with Amalfi coast
Appreciate the comments
Matera!

I visited both on the same trip. When I saw Positano, I was like: awww, this is so beautiful. When I went to Matera after, my first reaction was: HOW THIS PLACE CAN BE EVEN REAL???
So, yeah, even though they are very different, I would choose Matera. It was definitely the highlight of the trip.
Positano
Matera!!!

We're planning to do both in October, but we're going to Positano while staying in Sorrento and to Matera while staying in Monopoli. I would not want to a day trip to Positano from Monopoli or to Matera from Sorrento, so I think it's totally dependent on where you're staying. Choose the one that requires less of your day spent traveling and more spent enjoying, then stay in a different location on your next trip and see the other.
Positano

Been to both several times, and they are both completely different and unique. It's like asking which of your children do you like best?? It's impossible to answer. Maybe just base it on ease of logistics to where you are coming from, or where you need to return to.

They’re completely different! Both are amazing. Matera is a bit out of the way so if you can get there easily I’d say do it this time and leave Positano for another visit. What time of year are you going?

How often do you get to Italy?? Find the time to do both or you’ll regret it.
What’s a few extra days/$$ for an incredible lifetime experience?
Mattera, Positano is a mess this time of a year
Matera, hands down!
Angela Stewart Sessoms & Tami McGhee

Matera - a walking tour is a must to understand the history.
Positano was beautiful but so busy
Rya Garmay Christensen
Matera. Beautiful area - old world Italy. Not touristy at all

Depends where you are now! From Positano to Matera is around 230 km, which means cca 4 hours by car.
Positano is beautiful but crazy crowded and expensive. Matera is something unique and breath taking. I would definetely choose Matera and Basilicata and see that part of peaceful South Italy.
Positano
Matera very unique and less traveled. We stayed at an awesome cave hotel with a pool in the caves. (Can’t remember the name)
Matthew Silva
The best way to get to Matera from Sorrento
Positano
Positano
Positano

They are as different as night and day. No way to compare. One is on the coast with a possibility to take a boat and view of Amalfi coast, beach etc., the other is a stunning unique place not to be missed at some point in a lifetime.
So wonderful, take a Boston out on the water.
Positano, without a doubt!!
Luis Arturo Hernández Castro
Positano, it is heaven.
I loved Positano though very expensive!
I spent 4 days in Matera last year. An amazing place to explore
100% Matera
Matera for sure. So interesting!
Positano looks much better in person than photos. It’s just breathtaking and yes super busy during the day but mornings and evenings are quiet

Matera is amazing. You can see a coastal town everywhere but where else can you see a cave town. Totally worth it. Matera has gotten so popular lately. I’m glad we went before it got popular. It was one of our favorite stops on the way to Puglia.
We went to Matera in April and it was just magical! We stayed at a cave hotel which was outstanding and I highly recommend Sextantio | Le Grotte della Civita | Albergo Diffuso
Just did Amalfi coast and Positano last wee, amazing and spectacular. Loved it.

They are both fantastic to visit but only Matera you can do in one day. Positano is part of the most beautiful Amalfi Coast where you should visit for at least 5 days. You should drive the coastway, visit Positano, Sorrento, Amalfi and Ravello. Also make a boat tour from Sorrento to Amalfi. You can get of at Positano also. Picture is mine, taken from Villa Rufolo in Ravello.
Another good advice: Visit in april, May or September, otherwise it is far too crowdy!

You cann’t compare these 2 beauties … but I can almost 100% guarantee that you will be blown away by the beauty and uniqueness of Matera. I am. Or sure how much time you will have but a night and day in Matera is enough to savour the uniqueness of this place . Then if you have time .. Alberobello and the Valle d’itria is only an hour away.
If you decide to come . I can help with info and transfers…you won’t be sorry 🤗🤗🤗
Matera
Matera
When I went to Matera it was wet slippery. Positano, Amalfi and Ravello on the Amalfi Coast are far better for a visit
Just been to both Matera for me! So special and unique.
Please consider Matera. It's a unique ancient heritage destination. By day, it is breathtaking, by dusk it takes on another magnificent sight. Enjoy! 🌻
Matera…. for me!
Positano 💯

Matera is the oldest town in Italy and simply amazing. We stayed 3 days and I would have loved to stay longer and learn more. We did a lot of hiking and if you really want to explore Matera you should be up to do so….also not very toursity which I love whereas Positano is over run.

Best bar I’ve ever been to is in Matera. I felt like I was on the Flinstones!! 🤣🤣
Matera! ✨
Matera
Never been to Matera so can’t really say, but my son is still talking about Positano, Sorento and the Amalfi. They are breathtaking. A definite must see!!!
positano for me ✌🏼
I would take Positano.. hands down! I LOVED it! You can take side trips to Sorrento, Ravello, Isle of Capri, Salerno … beautiful town and experience!💕😜
Never been to Matera but we absolutely loved Positano

One word: MATERA!!
We were there two weeks ago to the day and we’re absolutely blown away. Breathtaking, mind blowing, words can’t capture its beauty. Don’t hesitate, you will never see anything else like it. A day I will never forget as long as I live 💕🇮🇹
Positano
Matera!!!! Positano is beautiful but requires more days!
Positano
Matera is unique. Positano has the charm of a hilly seaside location .

I haven’t been to Positano but Matera is just an experience you would be unlikely to ever have anywhere else. I absolutely loved it- it was the most beautiful and unique place I have ever visited. Just learn a little Italian to get by as the locals don’t speak a lot of English.
I had been in both last May. All Italy is wonderful. But if you prefer places not crowded, go to Matera and towns around.

Matera. I personally prefer Amalfi over Positano. Don't get me wrong, Positano is pretty, but it is just too much. Too many people, too many rules, too expensive. Matera is such an out of space experience, you can get super nice accomodation with nice views. I have been in both locations, when it was hot... Matera is just way better!

Oh they are so different! So unique both of them. I couldn’t choose one over the other. 🤩

Yes Matera, we stayed 3 nites in a cave hotel, very old and unbelievable, did a private walking tour with a wonderful guide and the history is mind blowing! Also been to Positano and Amalfi coast, they are beautiful but such different experience from Matera!

text: Recommendations for restaurants in Milan, Cinque terre, Florence, Figueres and Barcelona. Thank you

comments.comment_text:
For Barcelona I suggest you mescladis Borell.
Is a good restaurant but it’s also a social project that helps migrants people without documents to starts a career in restaurant business as server and cook.
Florence- il cinghiale bianco- - very old traditional florentine restaurant specialising in meat.

For Milan pizza club no limits…you will see, it’s a giro pizza! Very nice! For a restaurant: pane e tulipani near stazione centrale.
For an « apericena » Maya at Navigli.
Have a nice trip 🥳
For Florence, highly highly recommend La Giostra! Pear ravioli and tiramisu were divine. My husband had the filet and it also was delicious.
Montrosso I think near the train station.

Firenze “Buca Mario”, near Piazza di Santa Maria Novella, have the autentic tuscany cuisine. You have to try “crostini toscani” dish, it’s like my grandmother do them at home and also Fiorentina is a must.
Everytime i go to Firenze, i go there, it’s my favourite restaurant.
Another good and easy is “Buca Poldo” near Piazza della Signoria.

In Barcelona there is a place call “Bar Lobo” carrer Pintor Fortuny, near Buqueria Market, very nice bar restaurant for breakfast, lunch and dinner. A fixed stop everytime in my Barcelona trip.
I like also “Cal Pinxo” in Portvell, “Salamanca” in Barceloneta, “Orio” tapas bar in carrer de Ferran (near Ramblas and Placa Sant Jaume), and Les Quinze Nits in Paca Reial, a very nice place for dinner in barrio Gotico.

In Milano i like “Mamma Rosa” “il giglio rosso” “Mediterranea” (fish) all of them are near stazione centrale.

In Milan, some easy-going but delicious options are da Martino (well known for its Cotoletta alla milanese, Needs to be booked in advance), Osteria delle Commari (specialties from Rome/Latium area), la Taverna dei golosi.
Otherwise Ristorante Sa Mesa (Sardinian restaurant, the fish is very good), A' Riccione (fish, fancier), Trattoria a casa nostra
For pizza: Capuano's, Sorbillo, Da zero (gluten-free options as well) - usually they do not accept reservations, but they are fast and if you come early its easier
In CT go to Manarola and eat at Nessun Dorma. Our favorite there!

text: Hi, would like to plan a trip to Italy and Greek Islands. Don’t want to do too many touristy things, just the main (and most interesting ones) and then relax near a beach in hotels with water views. Prefer not to hire a car so any suggestions on getting around. Would also like to include a cruise but only on a small boat (200 people max). Also would love to do a foodie tour, any suggestions would be most appreciated

comments.comment_text:
Hi. Not sure when you’re planning to travel but currently there are wildfires in Rhodes & Corfu. Travelling round Italy is really easy - upload the Trentitalia app.

I’ve been going to Italy since I was 13 & recommend the following places - I’ve stayed in the hotel recommendations
this year.

Bologna, Padua, Lucca, Genoa, Parma, Verona, Asti, Piedmont, Florence, Pietrasanta, Puglia area, Sardinia & Sicily. Hired a car in Sardinia & Sicily. I could go on…. Been to Rome, Venice, Sorrento but prefer smaller cities/towns.

In Florence stay in the Oltrano area - across the bridge 10 mins walk to the sights but more authentic & less touristy.
Lucca is a beautiful walled city home of Puccini & much more. Recommend Insidethewall.i
t for a 5 roomed boutique place to stay. Sestri Levante is a lovely town in the Cinque Terre region - hotel Due Tori is right by the sea.

If you decide to do the beach area in Italy, I recommend the coast from Viareggio to Marina di Massa. Very Italian with few tourists just Italians in the summer holiday season. We hire bikes when we go here - cycle paths everywhere. Or we use the bus - frequent & cheap. Enjoy your trip.
Be careful of Rhodes and Corfu loads getting evacuated with heatwave and fires
Speaking of Greek island, Naxos is more relaxed and far less congested than Santorini or Mykonos.
Travel around mainland Italy, very easy by train and then fly directly to Greek Islands to relax on the beach, I recommend Paros and Milos
Take me 😆

text:
Hello, my family of 5 will be in Italy and France for 2-1/2 weeks departing in mid of August and I am trying to book train tickets online, but not sure if the following websites below are legit. Please advise me which website is trustworthy to purchase online.
1). Trenitalia 4). Raileurope
2). TheTrainLine 5). ItaloTreno
3). italiarail 6). Rail.ninja
Many thanks in advance!

comments.comment_text: Trentalia and train line are both good.
Trenitalia is the main company, Italo is another conpany, both web site are good and safe
1 and 5 are the official ones, run by the respective rail companies.

I use the Trainline app. Easy and straightforward
.
I booked straight with company italio private owned
What about Omio?
I use Trainline app :)

I have used Trainline for many, many years. I have looked at Omio, also a third-party service, and seems good. I have looked at Trenitalia and good but a tad more complicated than trainline, and likewise ItaloTreno. mainly issues with seat selection and categories of ticket, but they're OK. I would use any of them. I don't know the others. Some say only use the actual train company sites, which is fair ... tho if you're more likely to make mistakes because they're a bit less clear and friendly to non-Italian speakers then not sure what the advantage/risk mitigation is.

TRENITALIA or ITALOTRENO

On Trenitalia there are "Frecce" that are the "high-speed" trains
Italo is only "high-speed" but is a private company
The train line is brilliant
Trenitalia is the train service provider for a lot of train services in Italy.

You'll get people recommending them all.
I used the Trainline app for 13 trips in Italy and loved it. Mainly because it has trips from both companies.

The companies operating trains are:
1) Trenitalia: frecciarossa/
intercity/
regional trains (trenitalia.com)
2) NTV: italo train (italotreno.it)
So those are the only 2 official websites.

text:
Hi Peeps, we are planning a trip to Italy in second half of October. Mostly driving on a rented car. I am researching the time it takes to do a road trip from Pisa to Milan and am getting very confused with the estimates that pop up. the distance doesn't seem to be much but travel time without toll shown by google is close to 6 to 7hrs. Why does it take so much time to do 300 km trip? Is it advisable to do a road trip from Pisa to Milan via Portofino/Genoa in one day?
to those who lend their advice, appreciate your help in advance.

comments.comment_text:
It takes that long because half of the road is passing through Appennini mountain.

Edit i didn’t noticed you said 6 hours lol what. Hahahha

Trains are excellent and often and incredibly good value.

The roads are much slower (and very busy) as most things are in Italy - ‘piano piano’ ….

But if you’re set on doing so much in one day I’m sure you’ll get great comments below 👇
My Google and Apple Maps says 3 hours
Huh? Are you sure that you've enabled toll roads?
Small road, speed limits and traffic crossing town.

It’s 3 hours with toll roads, 6 hours with standard roads with maximum average speed of 50km/h but if you stop in Portofino probably it will be 6 hours because of the time you need from the highway to Portofino and back.
Take the toll roads. 3h12
See viamichelin.com for route plan and timing
Take a train, much less stressful.
The roads will not be all highways, that's why travelling takes time.
If you go cross country it is all hills and mountains, so windy roads, up and down, up and down. Some beautiful drives. But that's why it'll take you most of the day to drive Milano -Pisa.
Take the train.Easier, quicker, takes you straight to the center of town where cars are not allowed in many places and you risk a heftly fine.parking can be a nightmare too.
Go via Parma and La Spezia (A15/E33 and A1): ca. 3 and a half hours.
It takes longer without toll roads because the alternatives are narrower windy often coastal routes with lower speed limits. If time is your biggest factor use the toll roads
Keith Crossley

Pisa Milano 3 hours max 4. Here is: Milano, Parma,Fornovo,M
assa,Pisa. It'toll road (highway).
If you want to stop in Portofino, you must drive Milano, Genova, LaSpezia, Massa, Pisa. It's more traffic.

text: Hello all. Sorry if this is somehow unrelated. I'm in Rome with my daughter who's 8. We live in Ireland so she's not used with the heat. We're staying inside during the day, we have air conditioning, it's still warm though. The flight was delayed so she was exhausted when we arrived. Woke up with temperature that has been on and off and ableआणखी to control with paracetamol. She has bad stools too. But no pain or anything else and she's in good mood A friend nurse said it's the heat. Any advice on what I can give her here or where I can go for advice other than ER? I know this is a travel group and I'm not looking for medical advice just some suggestions. Thank you very much.

comments.comment_text: eat lightly, drink plenty of water and avoid the hottest hours to go out.
GO to the pharmacy and ask for Polase. It will restore the electrolytes. Drink lots of water

I went out in the extreme heat with no sunglasses a few days ago, got home and was dizzy/had a fever/💩. "Cold" shower and electrolytes (well, I had some water with salt and lemon actually, but you can go to a supermarket and buy any "sport drink"), some rest. I was dehidrated. The next day I was fine.
Drink plenty of water. If she’s chirpy go eat some pasta in the evening.

Go to the pharmacy/
chemist and ask them for probiotics/
fermenti lattici and electrolytes.
Gatorades drinks are also helpful.
Also if she’s sensitive to milk, in Italy the milk is “stronger” because is less diluted and if not used to it people can get an upset stomach.
I hope she feels better soon 🙂
Water / electrolyte drinks like power aide I have seen here. A cooling cloth around her neck
Aww poor thing hopefully she feels better soon
AA drink or aquarius sports drinks, with that you fill up salts and necessary minerals. It is almost the same as ORS.

We needed a doctor while we were in Rome and our host gave us this link. They were fast, cost nothing, open 24 hours and for tourists:

lity%20%2D%2006
0608.it
Pressure points to cool the body down are back of neck and inside wrists. Keep cool cloths on these areas to help. If she starts vomiting or cannot keep fluids down, straight to hospital/ doctor.
Give more fluids

Poor thing. Hope she feels better.
If you arrived and it started right after the flight etc., I doubt it can be from the heat since you haven’t experienced it yet. Maybe something she ate on the plane or just from the change in pressure on the flight in general.
Poweraid is very good for rehydration

Several people have recommended specific things to get from a farmacia, but another thing to do would be to just go to one and describe the symptoms. The pharmacists are really great, competent and helpful and might know best what local medication will be effective.
Sounds like she is dehydrated. Start with the electrolyte drink, make sure she drinks a lot of water (not soda/pop nor juice)
Try with Guardia medica, it's a free service for minor emergencies. It is usually on at night.
Enrica Palla
I used doctors in Italy a couple of weeks ago for a virtual visit. 20euro and got fixed up quick! Hope she feels well soon!
Farmacia

If you are still in need of help the website doctorsinitaly is a great resource.Please
don’t just give electrolytes until you know what is happening. Visit a pharmacy, they can also give you suggestions.
At the least needs aggressive rehydration
Pedialyte drinks( not sure if you find in Italy)
Gatorade, propel, pedialyte. Anything with electrolytes. Keep her well hydrated
Liquid IV for hydration!

Hope she’s feeling better. After she’s had her electrolytes, cool down the pressure points, cold wet face wash on forehead and keep sipping water throughout the day. Keep drinks regular and avoid skulling/
gulping down a lot of water at once as that can make you feel sick. Put wet face washes in the fridge to put on back of neck if it gets hotter. I’d keep up the Panadol another day to beat that fever.

Try this, incredibly helpful and fast appointments
https://
www.doctorsinita
ly.com/
Definitely the electrolytes! If you can find real pure coconut water that’s better than regular water!
Keep her as hydrated as possible with electrolyte drinks.
Teva is an Italian brand of hydralite. Try that. 1 morning and night while this heat persists.
Thank you all very much 🙏
Go to pharmacy or farmacia and ask for electrolyte drink tablets. Put in water and drink. Then plenty of fluids. They are like sports drinks, athletes have.
Can you get something like hydralyte. It’s good for dehydration and after gastro.
A wet hanky tied around the neck is good too.
If your hotel room has a bath, run a tepid bath to help bring her core body temp down. Lots of fluids, ice blocks/ice if possible. Hope she is feeling better soon
Limit clothing and have a cool bath. Hydrate with electrolytes and avoid salty foods. If no change in 24hrs or she becomes worse, straight to ER.

text: Hi, my partner and I are taking a day trip to Genoa in our hire car tomorrow morning. I know it doesn't get the best rep on here compared to other cities, but we're still going anyway as part of our Italian tour 💁🏻‍♀️we know about the smaller coastal towns outside of the city, so I'm looking for recommendations of things/specific places to do, see and eat in the city. AND if anyone can give us an idea of where we can park for free, or relatively cheaply, even better! 😁🥰

comments.comment_text:
Genoa is famous for the Strade Nuove (Via Giuseppe Garibaldi, Via Balbi, Via Cairoli) (1778-1786, formerly Strada Nuovissima) and Palazzi dei Rolli (both UNESCO world heritage site).
The Royal Palace and the Ducal/Doge's Palace are quite beautiful too, as the National Gallery.
The Aquarium I think it is still the biggest in Europe.
I had good reviews also of the Galata, the maritime museum.

Go to the Monumental Cemetery of Staglieno. The place is amazing. Additionally, I would recommend a visit to Santa Maria di Castello. Once inside ask for the free monastery tour. Genoa is so charming. We loved our time there.
Visit the Christofer Columbus house, San Lorenzo Cathedral, Royal Palace Museum, the Aquarium and take a harbor cruise (very interesting!).

The city is kind of particular. Sincerely not beautiful in a canonical point of view, but interesting.
I suggest the Acquarium, which is wonderful, but take quite a long time to visit.
Then there is the Maritime Museum which is really underrated and so interesting. If you are into history of the sea and the immigration/
emigration is something deserve a visit.
About place to eat it’s been a while but I liked Trattoria Vegia Zena and osteria il Cadraio. Give them a shot

Genoa is gorgeous to just wander around and get lost in the cobbled streets and check out the architecture. It has a fabulous maritime museum on the waterfront. You can take free funiculars up to get panoramic views of the city.
So weird nobody suggested Cinque Terre, given that it's in the same region! Just hit any inquiry about trips outside Florence and it's always on the list... 😂
It head north in to the mountains. It is cool and beautiful

Hi folks, thank you for all of your suggestions! Just to clarify, we are going to the city, not anywhere outside of it - no towns, mountains, etc. We've done loads of that on this trip so far. We're looking for recommendations
of things to do for one day in the city of Genoa! We're en route now 🙂 if anyone can recommend any parking, that would be amazing!
Pesto originated in Genoa so sample some in any trattoria. Enjoy your time there - we had 4 days there 10 years ago. Loads to see & do.
Look on google which is the closest “migliore focaccia di Genova” (best focaccia in Genova) and eat focaccia di Recco (ie cheese focaccia): you’ll be blown away!

Go to the old historic area. Go to the port. You can drive down the coast to Recco and Camogli and check out the beach. We were there in May and loved it so much were going back next year to spend more time there. I think it's really underrated.

text:

Also, we really want to visit Capri, but from everything I’ve read, it’s best enjoyed once the ferries stop for the day - meaning the evening/night time, once the huge crowds of tourists not staying on the island have left.

We already have our hotel booked in Naples, and we’re not going to adjust that - but would it be completely absurd to take the last ferry to Capri in the late afternoon (whichever the last is), book a hotel for one night on Capri so we can enjoy the hours after the ferries have gone for the day, maybe enjoy the beach and go up to Anacapri (spelling?) the next morning/early afternoon - before heading back to Napoli?

I want us to have the best and most authentic experience in Capri as possible. Does this sounds nuts? Or how would you do it?

Also, when do the beaches and stores in Capri typically close the last week of August? And are there any night clubs or dancing on the island as well?

I really appreciate any insight. Grazie, and have the best day! ❤️🌻

I am also a fan of Napoli <3 Have you been to Ischia? Not as dramatic as Capri but hot spring baths and Castel Aragonese are pretty special. Buon viaggio
I would go off season 🤷🏻‍♀️but if you can afford it, sure: double book

I was in smaller places in Italy.... I didn't see night clubs 🤔

Hi, I am trying to book a stay at a hotel in Rome. Their website states to contact them for rates. I received an email from them with their rates, and it is cheaper than any of the third party sites offer. However there is no way to book directly on their website, and the owner is asking for either credit card information or Bank transfer.

Thoughts on this? I would love to get the cheaper rate, but want to make sure this seems legitimate. If I do go through with it which option would be safer?

comments.comment_text: I’ve done this before, given my credit card details via email. It’s just a guarantee of arrival. I’d be concerned if they didn’t ask. At the end of the day, if they charge without your ok, you can dispute it. But it’s quite normal with smaller places that aren’t your big hotels.
If you do this, maybe send the info via what’s app - email is not secure
I’ve transferred accommodation deposit money securely before and it’s always been ok. I think it was a PayPal transfer back then but there are many ways of doing it and I expect most are fine.
I personally would never send my back details/credit card info in an email. But I would pay by bank transfer straight into their account

Bank transfer is very common practice in Italy. But it’s not that easy for us who do not live there. It’s very common to guarantee the booking by providing your credit card information. My most recent booking, for example, is with a B&B. Innkeeper sent me a secure link to make a transaction via WhatsApp. If you feel uncomfortable, then look for a place who takes online booking
Just do a bank transfer from your bank app then you're not giving them your details just the money for the booking.

And what booking policy says about payment time and cancellation? They are asking for details as guarantee and some of hotels only charge days before arrival or on arrival day if you are not canceling. If they are charging any money as not mentioned in policy you can dispute as people already told you.

Plus, access to the sights is always better in the center rather than on the outskirts. Just rolling out of your door in the morning and being able to walk everywhere is a wonderful thing. That proximity makes it easy to get to an attraction before those staying farther away can arrive. So it’s a way to beat some of the crowds. And not having far to go far at night to get to your room after a full day of sightseeing is great for a tired tourist. So whenever possible I always choose the center for both atmosphere & convenience.

We long ago gave up on the daytime crowds in Florence, the "skip the line" lines, and one tour group after the next. But we like to walk the streets in the morning and love the evening atmosphere. We did a private water taxi. Someone was waiting for us at the airport and took us to the taxi. Great view of the city on the ride in and ride out to the train!

Look up the stops and get the Vaporetto (which is basically the Venetian version of public transport), - they leave from the steps in front of the train station, then get off at the stop closest to your hotel and walk. Unless you have money to burn avoid the water taxis at all costs.
Take the vaporetto.

You can buy the vaporetto pass when you walk out of the train station or you can buy it online ahead of time. We bought the 3 day pass online before hand. We brought the print out of the purchase and all we had to do was scan the QR codes from the paper and the machine at the ticket station printed our water passes.. was very easy! I called our hotel ahead of time and asked which vaporetto line we needed to take which was helpful when we arrived.

Ask your hotel to arrange a water taxi, it might be cheaper than you getting one at the station. The vaporetto stops at all the stops and getting in that after a long plane ride was long and exhausting.

text: Please help. Next month is our 25th anniversary and we plan to visit Italy for the first time. Arriving Aug 25th and staying for 10-14 days. We are struggling with deciding between the following trips. Which do you recommend and why?

comments.comment_text: Puglia & Basilicata any time. Fewer tourists, many sites to see and awesome food.

U will have a good time in any of the places you’ve listed, but south of Naples English is less common and public transportation links fewer. The key, wherever you decide to go, is to relax and not try to do/see too much. It is impossible to see everything on a single trip. Do some significant research before u go so u know what u would like to do and see before u are on the ground in Italy.

Really depends on what you want to get out of the vacation.
Museum and history- Rome and Florence.
Laid back and nature - Swiss Alps- Lake Como
Etc
Normally I'd vote for Sicily or Puglia, but I'm afraid the heat will not make it enjoyable in August. I'd try and stay in the Northern regions, and even go up into the Dolomites.
First itinerary- Venice, etc. Avoid Sicily. It’s a disaster to get into and out of right now due to fires.
I voted for the North Italy/ Switzerland trip due to August being so Hot and thought maybe it would be less crowded 🤷
Next mont? August 2024? You might be way too late to book accommodations and flights !
I’d go with the first but I’d skip cinque Terre and visit a few more small towns in Tuscany
I say the first option but leave out 2 of them.
There is no city in the world like Roma. I believe you will go to Italy more than once in your life— just wait!
No Milan. Sorrento. Rome. Florence. Venice.
Northern Italy in August due to heat.

So hard because the north is so different from the south. I loved Rome but also loved Naples, and Sienna... i could retire there.

All so beautiful
But italy is somewhere u go more than once. So with that being said ..enjoy each place ..dont rush it.

We Italians love to visit those cities in the mezze stagioni (middle seasons: spring or fall) but from June to September they are too hot and we go on holiday by the seaside or the mointains

To me you haven't seen or experienced Italy until you've been to Rome. Bare in mind though that Italy is really hot in summer so the further south you go the worse it gets, if you don't do well in humidity then you should maybe rethink Rome in August.
I'm from Venice, it gets REALLY hot in summer and it's crowded af, would not suggest to visit it in August

Don’t need to leave Italy to get Swiss alps views and vibes! Noticing the Dolomites aren’t on there and they are 😍😍😍 could add cinque terre and the Dolomites to number 2 if you want to stay within Italy

First time I did Venice, Florence, Cinque Terre, Tarquania, Ponza and Rome and it was AMAZING~ Yu can stay in Venice for three nights and do a day trip to the Dolomites which would give that "Swiss Alps" vibe!

Ciao.
Se vieni in Italia una volta nella vita sicuramente io al tuo posto farei: Roma, Firenze e citta toscane (Lucca e Siena sono stupende), Venezia e Milano.
Napoli, costiera Amalfitana e Sicilia sono meravigliose. Ma anche il nord Italia con laghi e montagne è fantastico. Le Alpi tra Italia e Svizzera sono bellissime.
Dipende da cosa preferisci vedere,se più natura o arte.

Se opti per le montagne e la Svizzera considera che rispetto all'Italia la Svizzera è cara.
Buon viaggio!

1st of all there is a big difference between 10 days and 14 days. I'd op for 10 days which should NOT include arriving and departing on either end. All are amazing, different unique, and beautiful. That being said, I say option 1 but not as many places, Rome, Florence, and Venice are plenty. I'd skip Sicily, Sicily is like its own country, and spending the entire time there is reasonable.
We just celebrated our 30. Venice, Florence, Cinque Terre, Rome, Venice.

Venice, Florence, Siena and Cinque Terre. Skip Rome for another trip
Choice one for first timers! You’ll be back! Then take the others!

text: Travelling in November. My husband wants to visit Pompeii with our kids (12 and 14) while I attend a conference in Rome. Any recommendations on how to get there and any tours? Thank you!

comments.comment_text:
Fast Train to Napoli -> Train (transvesuvio) to pompeii-> visiting -> Same way Back.

Possible in a day.
Train. You can find a local guide when you get there. Supports the local economy. Trains are wonderful and you can get your tickets in advance.
They should also visit Herculaneum.
I think in august will start to operate a train that goes directly from Rome to Pompeii. Try to Google it.

This isn’t going to be super helpful. We took the train from Sorrento and you get off the train right across the street. We took the train to Naples gate for pizza. It was Super convenient.

I can’t find the tour guide info. But the advice I can give is schedule your tour right when they open. You avoid the heat and the crowds. It made it tolerable for our kids. It was great.
It’s worth hiring a guide to walk you around in Pompeii. You can do so when you get there. The kids will be free for entry. Train available from Rome.

It's a very simple train ride, Rome to Naples, Naples to Pompeii Trenitalia or CCircumvesuvian
a/Campania Express. One piece of advice, there are three entrances into Pompeii, one at the train stop(Porta Marina) another down the hill (Piazza Esedra) , where all souvenirs are cheaper than by the train stop and another further down on( Piazza Anfiteatro), closer into town. This is the best entrance, with the most too see and enjoy, especially with kids.
We did a bus tour (from Rome) of Pompeii through Viator. Really enjoyed it.

Years ago I booked a tour. Basically it was just bus transportation to Pompeii and back with a bathroom stop in the middle. It was inexpensive and a great way for my mom and I to travel to Pompeii. I wasn't comfortable navigating the trains.
There is no shade at Pompeii - so dress appropriately and take sunscreen. Also be mindful on the trains if your possessions. We loved visiting Pompeii.
Do a search on the home page and there are oodles of info 👍🏽👍🏽

I'm pleased you are taking your children to
Pompei. Went there a couple of years ago and it was fantastic.
We organised a tour on a bus and with a tour guide, picked us up at a cafe in the piazza in Rome 😊

Book through Viator and make sure it's Askos Tours. We just had our tour last weekend. These tours are guided by archeologists and in very small groups. Very thorough in all the explanations of what happened. We'd definitely do this tour again in the future. Very reasonably priced too!

The new high speed train from Rome to Pompeii only operates the third Sunday of the month. Viator offers day trips.
And this from a Google Search:
With several departures per hour, the fast frecciarossa trains from Rome to Naples followed by the local train to Pompeii is the best way to do a day trip on your own. Your travel time from Roma Termini to Pompeii is around 2 hours and the station for Pompeii is right outside the main entrance.
We took a train that literally drops you off in front of Pompeii and we toured and went back.

We got a self guide audio tour - went when it opened at 9am much better than a tour ! We went straight to the back of pompeii and worked our way back to the exit - booked through Headout skip the line with self guide audio , teen daughter thought this was better than a tour
Booking a tour guide is a very good idea and your children will learn a great deal more than if you go it alone.
Be sure to get the air conditioned train! My opinion you should do the tour/guide. So much incredible information that you would never learn without a guide!

text:
Good morning! Looking for some honeymoon recommendations and inspiration...

We are doing a destination wedding in Umbria in July 2024 and are planning to honeymoon right after. We will have 10-14 days for the honeymoon and would like to stay in Northern Italy (Florence and above). We want to make the most of our time in Italy, but are also mindfulआणखी that we will want to relax a bit after a busy wedding week.
Some of our thoughts so far include:
-Florence (with day trips to vineyards etc)
-Cinque Terre
-Lake Como (a must for us, and want to spend at least a couple days here)
-Venice

Any other must visit towns or locations? Any recommendations on how many days to stay in each location, and the best way to get between them (we don't mind renting a car).

I should note that we need to fly back to the US at the end, so will need to end in a larger city to make catching a flight easier.

Thank you in advanced!

comments.comment_text: Get married at home and honeymoon in Italy, avoid all the hassle

Appr. 30 mins by car from Venice:
De Stefani winery
Cioccolateria Veneziana
Also recommend to visít Caorle with beautiful historical town and long, sandy beach
Lake Como, you will adore it and never want to come back

Spend as much time as possible in the Italian Lake District, such as Lake Como or other village, then a few days in Milan for seeing the important sights (the original fresco of The Last Supper) etc, then fly out of Milan. I did this and it worked perfectly, but that was 20 years ago.

I know you say that Lake Como is a must, but we were there for a day trip in June (Bellagio) and it was ridiculously crowded — to the point that it was not enjoyable. We stayed in Stresa on Lake Maggiore and absolutely LOVED it! It was stunning and sooo relaxing. Our second favorite city that we visited was Verona. Such a great vibe in that city.
My daughter got married in Umbria! It was magical!
After visiting a couple weeks ago, I’m pushing Ortisei as the place to be in the summer. It is one of the most beautiful places in Italy and temps in mid 70s while Florence is in the 90s.

Our son had his destination wedding in Puglia 5 years ago. It was magical.
Northern Italy is so fabulous. You can end your trip in Venice and fly home from there. Lake Como and Lago Maggiore and both wonderful. Lago di Garda is gorgeous. Try to stay in just a few places so you can relax.
Otherwise you will be spending too much time in the car!
I would recommend renting a car. Congratulations
. A great way to begin your life together .

Well Umbria is really nice, somehow a more rustic version of Tuscany.
Montefalco, Assisi and Orvieto are really nice and in the area there are winery and olive oil.
If you heading north in Veneto region I can suggest you to visit Valdobbiadene area. I know it’s where I live but the area is lovely and if you want to do a Prosecco tasting, my family winery is open for you.
Personally I suggest you to make a radical decision. In just one trip is hard to fit everything, maybe do less but do more. I mean a day trip to 5 Terre is nice but you’ll just be able to do a couple of pictures and that’s it
Dolomites are lovely! Cortina is beautiful but more of an Alpine feeling!
I love Assi too!

I live in Valsolda, Italy, on Lake Lugano (or as the Italians call it, Lake Ceresio). Our town is a tiny, quiet town, 10 minutes from the border of Switzerland, and a 20 minute drive from the town of Menaggio on Lake Como. If you travel around Lake Como, which is certainly more touristy, and are looking for nature and relaxation, check out my area. We’ve got hiking paths, lakeside relaxation with no crowds, natural mountain springs, boat rentals and so much more. I’m biased, but…

text:
Hi all I just want some advice on buying a euro rail pass I’ll be travelling through Italy for 2 weeks and other parts of Europe for another 2 what is the best option to choose for the euro rail pass I’ll be traveling between places most days/ every second to third day so will definitely be using the train a lot any suggestions?

Thank you in advance

comments.comment_text: following

Very hard to answer. If you plan and buy rail tickets early, sometimes it can be more cost effective to buy them from the rail providers. If you want flexibility to change destination/
day/time of travel then a Eurail/ Interrail pass may be best for you.
Sketch out a plan of where you want to go, get on each countries rail service provider sites and work out what the cost is for next week and when you expect to travel, because sometimes the earlier you buy tickets the cheaper they will be. Once you have an idea of prices check to see if there is a Eurail pass that saves you money.
I just bought the tickets a day or two in advance. Only did 4 journeys so didn't think the rail pass would be cheaper. Worked out ok for us.

I know this group is travel tip sharing group. But I can’t think of any other better group to ask for advices. I am from Myanmar. I am going to Venice in coming September for University.
But I am struggling to find a single room to live for a year in Venice. I am in several groups of housing.
I saw many posts of houses for tenants. I always dm themआणखी as fast as I can. But neither of them read and reply our messages🙂. So what is the point of inviting tenants when they have no intention to reply us🙂. All I can think about is this active group.
I know people in this group are kind and enthusiastic to share great tips and experiences.
So if you have any tips about renting a room in Italy
or if you know someone who rents rooms in Italy, please let me know. I really need you guys’ help.
Thank you so much for your attention.

comments.comment_text: Several students have rented my Airbnb room for a month or so while they settle in the UK (not Italy, sorry) and find somewhere else to stay. I suspect it's easier to do that. Many Airbnb hosts offer significant discounts for a week, month, or whatever. It might be worth looking at.
Try looking in nearby Mestre. Probably more options and more affordable.
The university should be able to help steer you in the right direction. Contact their student housing office.
Find a room in a cheap airbnb for the first month, in Mestre.When you are there it will be easier
I believe that, in Venice there are monasteries that rent rooms to students.

You could possibly also live in Padua, it has its own university so there are lots of students and it’s only 20mins to Santa Lucia (the Venice islands) train station. The trains are very regular. I lived in Padua and it was very easy to get to Venice from there. I would suggest accommodation Facebook groups. I used to be in one for Padova and it was very helpful
Commuting is an option you should consider. Last time I visited Venice, I stayed just outside Padua and travelled in and out of Venice.
I would book an air bnb for the first few weeks, once you are there you will meet other people and students and you could house share, local contacts will be more helpful in person.
Have you joined any Erasmus group here on facebook, e.g. Erasmus a Venezia affitti case e stanze? You can post a message there saying you are looking for a room
Have you joined this group?
Also this group
Maybe contact some short term rental owners. You may hit one that is fed up with short term gigs and would welcome a year long stay.
It would be much easier to look for a room in Mestre.

the lack of rooms for university students (unless you are willing to pay way too much) is a known problem in Italy, so much so that it's in the news sometimes and that there are discussions in the Parliament about it. It isn't of course always hard (it also depends on the city) or as hard as it is being in your case, but it's a big issue for many students. My advice is to look in neighboring towns, you may end up spending less than living in venice even when taking commuting into account.

text: Ok, I tried the search but my head hurts. Taking the train from Venice to Florence. We don't want seats that face backwards. Which direction is the front of the train? Car 1 or Car 6 (assuming the train doesn't turn around to where Car 1 is always the front)? 😂🤯😭

comments.comment_text: Ok so I was on the train from rome to venice I booked 8 a 8b 8c 8 d. Big mistake as we were separated by the middle aisle. I should have booked 8a 8b 9a 9b to sit together. And the train changed directions after one of the stops. I get motion sickness and the train was rough for me. This is just me. I'm a hot mess with motion sickness had I realized I would have put on my air sickness patch

We took the fast train from Paris to Lourdes and at first I was sitting backwards (for all of 30 seconds) and then moved to forward facing. I don't tend to get motion sickness but going as fast as we were, I felt queasy. We booked first class and it wasn't crowded at all. There were 3 of us so we had our own little section with a table in the middle.
But I don't know if you can tell prior unless you study the seating arrangements and know which way the train is headed.
Ask at the station.
It changes depending on how the trains have moved around the tracks between destinations.

I didn't reserve seats. I can't go backwards for more than 30 minutes. If I saw the train approaching I'd just find a seat facing forwards. If the train was stationary and could go either way I asked people or moved.
Ville Lignell

No way to predict. Some stations have the trains going thru while others all come in perpendicular to the entrance (Venice, Rome and Florence are all the latter), so the front of the train coming in is the last car going out.
You could get seats facing each other so at least one of you is facing forward.
No way to predict but on one of the ways when we got them facing backwards, I told the conductor I get motion sickness and they moved us to forward facing seats.
u can't predict it .. maybe book a car instead...
